load.Describ: The load average of the machine describes how many processes are in the run-queue (scheduled to run "immediately").
load.Title: Load average

entropy.Describ: This graph shows the amount of entropy available in the system.
entropy.Title: Available entropy

entropy.info: The number of random bytes available. This is typically used by cryptographic applications.
entropy.label: entropy

if_eth2.Describ: This graph shows the traffic of the eth2 network interface. Please note that the traffic is shown in bits per second, not bytes. IMPORTANT: On 32-bit systems the data source for this plugin uses 32-bit counters, which makes the plugin unreliable and unsuitable for most 100-Mb/s (or faster) interfaces, where traffic is expected to exceed 50 Mb/s over a 5 minute period.  This means that this plugin is unsuitable for most 32-bit production environments. To avoid this problem, use the ip_ plugin instead.  There should be no problems on 64-bit systems running 64-bit kernels.
if_eth2.Title: eth2 traffic

up.info: Traffic of the eth2 interface. Unable to determine interface speed. Please install ethtool, wireless-tools, mii-tool or whatever is appropriate for the interface.
up.label: bps

if_vnet2.Describ: This graph shows the traffic of the vnet2 network interface. Please note that the traffic is shown in bits per second, not bytes. This means that this plugin is unsuitable for most 32-bit production environments. To avoid this problem, use the ip_ plugin instead.  There should be no problems on 64-bit systems running 64-bit kernels.
if_vnet2.Title: vnet2 traffic

up.info: Traffic of the vnet2 interface. Unable to determine interface speed. Please install ethtool, wireless-tools, mii-tool or whatever is appropriate for the interface.
up.label: bps

memory.Describ: This graph shows what the machine uses memory for.
memory.Title: Memory usage

free.info: Wasted memory. Memory that is not used for anything at all.
free.label: unused

swap_cache.info: A piece of memory that keeps track of pages that have been fetched from swap but not yet been modified.
swap_cache.label: swap_cache

active.info: Memory recently used. Not reclaimed unless absolutely necessary.
active.label: active

committed.info: The amount of memory allocated to programs. Overcommitting is normal, but may indicate memory leaks.
committed.label: committed

page_tables.info: Memory used to map between virtual and physical memory addresses.
page_tables.label: page_tables

slab.info: Memory used by the kernel (major users  are caches like inode, dentry, etc).
slab.label: slab_cache

buffers.info: Block device (e.g. harddisk) cache. Also where "dirty" blocks are stored until written.
buffers.label: buffers

memory.Order: apps page_tables swap_cache slab cached buffers free swap

libvirt-cputime.Describ: This graph shows the cpu time percentage of each virtual machine
libvirt-cputime.Title: Virtual Domain Cpu Time

total_pc.info: cputime used by all virtual machines
total_pc.label: total

instance_000007be_cputime.info: percent of cputime used by virtual machine 'instance-000007be'
instance_000007be_cputime.label: instance-000007be

instance_000005df_cputime.info: percent of cputime used by virtual machine 'instance-000005df'
instance_000005df_cputime.label: instance-000005df

instance_000007ca_cputime.info: percent of cputime used by virtual machine 'instance-000007ca'
instance_000007ca_cputime.label: instance-000007ca

instance_00002298_cputime.info: percent of cputime used by virtual machine 'instance-00002298'
instance_00002298_cputime.label: instance-00002298

instance_00000654_cputime.info: percent of cputime used by virtual machine 'instance-00000654'
instance_00000654_cputime.label: instance-00000654

instance_00001c84_cputime.info: percent of cputime used by virtual machine 'instance-00001c84'
instance_00001c84_cputime.label: instance-00001c84

instance_00002319_cputime.info: percent of cputime used by virtual machine 'instance-00002319'
instance_00002319_cputime.label: instance-00002319

forks.Describ: This graph shows the number of forks (new processes started) per second.
forks.Title: Fork rate

forks.info: The number of forks per second.
forks.label: forks

if_err_vlan1001.Title: vlan1001 errors, drops, and collisions

proc_pri.Describ: This graph shows number of processes at each priority
proc_pri.Title: Processes priority

locked.info: The number of processes that have pages locked into memory (for real-time and custom IO)
locked.label: locked in memory

libvirt-ifstat.Describ: This graph shows the network I/O of the virtual machines
libvirt-ifstat.Title: Virtual Domain Network I/O

interrupts.Describ: This graph shows the number of interrupts and context switches on the system. These are typically high on a busy system.
interrupts.Title: Interrupts and context switches

ctx.info: A context switch occurs when a multitasking operatings system suspends the currently running process, and starts executing another.
ctx.label: context switches

intr.info: Interrupts are events that alter sequence of instructions executed by a processor. They can come from either hardware (exceptions, NMI, IRQ) or software.
intr.label: interrupts

if_vlan1000.Describ: This graph shows the traffic of the vlan1000 network interface. Please note that the traffic is shown in bits per second, not bytes. IMPORTANT: On 32-bit systems the data source for this plugin uses 32-bit counters, which makes the plugin unreliable and unsuitable for most 100-Mb/s (or faster) interfaces, where traffic is expected to exceed 50 Mb/s over a 5 minute period.  This means that this plugin is unsuitable for most 32-bit production environments. To avoid this problem, use the ip_ plugin instead.  There should be no problems on 64-bit systems running 64-bit kernels.
if_vlan1000.Title: vlan1000 traffic

up.info: Traffic of the vlan1000 interface. Maximum speed is 1000 Mb/s.
up.label: bps

if_err_eth3.100.Describ: This graph shows the amount of errors, packet drops, and collisions on the eth3.100 network interface.
if_err_eth3.100.Title: eth3.100 errors, drops, and collisions

processes.Describ: This graph shows the number of processes
processes.Title: Processes

uninterruptible.info: The number of uninterruptible processes (usually IO).
uninterruptible.label: uninterruptible

runnable.info: The number of runnable processes (on the run queue).
runnable.label: runnable

zombie.info: The number of defunct (zombie) processes (process terminated and parent not waiting).
zombie.label: zombie

paging.info: The number of paging processes (<2.6 kernels only).
paging.label: paging

stopped.info: The number of stopped or traced processes.
stopped.label: stopped

processes.Order: sleeping stopped zombie dead paging uninterruptible runnable processes

irqstats.Describ: Shows the number of different IRQs received by the kernel.  High disk or network traffic can cause a high number of interrupts (with good hardware and drivers this will be less so). Sudden high interrupt activity with no associated higher system activity is not normal.
irqstats.Title: Individual interrupts

iTLB.info: Interrupt TLB, for device(s): TLB shootdowns
iTLB.label: TLB shootdowns

iTHR.info: Interrupt THR, for device(s): Threshold APIC interrupts
iTHR.label: Threshold APIC interrupts

iMCE.info: Interrupt MCE, for device(s): Machine check exceptions
iMCE.label: Machine check exceptions

iSPU.info: Interrupt SPU, for device(s): Spurious interrupts
iSPU.label: Spurious interrupts

iRES.info: Interrupt RES, for device(s): Rescheduling interrupts
iRES.label: Rescheduling interrupts

iCAL.info: Interrupt CAL, for device(s): Function call interrupts
iCAL.label: Function call interrupts

iMCP.info: Interrupt MCP, for device(s): Machine check polls
iMCP.label: Machine check polls

iLOC.info: Interrupt LOC, for device(s): Local timer interrupts
iLOC.label: Local timer interrupts

iIWI.info: Interrupt IWI, for device(s): IRQ work interrupts
iIWI.label: IRQ work interrupts

iTRM.info: Interrupt TRM, for device(s): Thermal event interrupts
iTRM.label: Thermal event interrupts

iPMI.info: Interrupt PMI, for device(s): Performance monitoring interrupts
iPMI.label: Performance monitoring interrupts

iNMI.info: Interrupt NMI, for device(s): Non-maskable interrupts
iNMI.label: Non-maskable interrupts

irqstats.Order: i0 i1 i8 i9 i12 i17 i20 i22 i23 i64 i68 i72 i76 i77 i78 i79 i80 i81 i82 i83 iNMI iLOC iSPU iPMI iIWI iRES iCAL iTLB iTRM iTHR iMCE iMCP iERR iMIS

if_err_br1020.Describ: This graph shows the amount of errors, packet drops, and collisions on the br1020 network interface.
if_err_br1020.Title: br1020 errors, drops, and collisions

libvirt-mem.Describ: This graph shows the current amount of memory used by each virtual machine
libvirt-mem.Title: Virtual Domain Memory Usage

total_pc.info: memory in percent used by virtual machines on host 'compute1.enocloud.com'
total_pc.label: used memory percentage

total_max_pc.info: maximum memory in percent virtual machines can balloon to on host 'compute1.enocloud.com'
total_max_pc.label: total maximum memory percentage

total.info: total memory used by virtual machines on host 'compute1.enocloud.com'
total.label: total memory

total_max.info: maximum memory virtual machines can balloon to on host 'compute1.enocloud.com'
total_max.label: total max. mem

threads.Describ: This graph shows the number of threads.
threads.Title: Number of threads

if_err_br1027.Describ: This graph shows the amount of errors, packet drops, and collisions on the br1027 network interface.
if_err_br1027.Title: br1027 errors, drops, and collisions

open_inodes.Describ: This graph monitors the Linux open inode table.
open_inodes.Title: Inode table usage

max.info: The size of the system inode table. This is dynamically adjusted by the kernel.
max.label: inode table size

used.info: The number of currently open inodes.
used.label: open inodes

max.label: max open files

used.info: The number of currently open files.
used.label: open files

if_err_eth2.Describ: This graph shows the amount of errors, packet drops, and collisions on the eth2 network interface.
if_err_eth2.Title: eth2 errors, drops, and collisions

if_br1005.Describ: This graph shows the traffic of the br1005 network interface. Please note that the traffic is shown in bits per second, not bytes. IMPORTANT: On 32-bit systems the data source for this plugin uses 32-bit counters, which makes the plugin unreliable and unsuitable for most 100-Mb/s (or faster) interfaces, where traffic is expected to exceed 50 Mb/s over a 5 minute period.  This means that this plugin is unsuitable for most 32-bit production environments. To avoid this problem, use the ip_ plugin instead.  There should be no problems on 64-bit systems running 64-bit kernels.
if_br1005.Title: br1005 traffic

up.info: Traffic of the br1005 interface. Unable to determine interface speed. Please install ethtool, wireless-tools, mii-tool or whatever is appropriate for the interface.
up.label: bps

if_err_vlan1036.Describ: This graph shows the amount of errors, packet drops, and collisions on the vlan1036 network interface.
if_err_vlan1036.Title: vlan1036 errors, drops, and collisions

cpu.Describ: This graph shows how CPU time is spent.
cpu.Title: CPU usage

iowait.info: CPU time spent waiting for I/O operations to finish when there is nothing else to do.
iowait.label: iowait

system.info: CPU time spent by the kernel in system activities
system.label: system

user.info: CPU time spent by normal programs and daemons
user.label: user

nice.info: CPU time spent by nice(1)d programs
nice.label: nice

steal.info: The time that a virtual CPU had runnable tasks, but the virtual CPU itself was not running
steal.label: steal

guest.info: The time spent running a virtual CPU for guest operating systems under the control of the Linux kernel.
guest.label: guest

cpu.Order: system user nice idle iowait irq softirq
